title: My Personal Webpage
text: title: “Machine Learning – Concise Notes” author: “Aiswarya G” format: html: toc: true number-sections: true theme: cosmo pdf: toc: true number-sections: true execute: echo: true warning: false message: false ————–

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
1. Introduction to Machine Learning
Machine Learning (ML) enables systems to learn patterns from data and make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed.

Types of ML

Supervised Learning: Labeled data (Classification, Regression)
Unsupervised Learning: Unlabeled data (Clustering, Dimensionality Reduction)
Semi-supervised Learning: Small labeled + large unlabeled data
Reinforcement Learning: Agent–environment interaction



Typical ML Pipeline

Data collection
Preprocessing
Feature extraction/selection
Model training
Evaluation
Deployment

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
2. Mathematical Foundations

Linear Algebra

Vectors, matrices
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors
Matrix norms



Probability & Statistics

Random variables
Expectation, variance
Bayes theorem



Optimization

Convex vs non-convex functions
Gradient descent variants

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
3. Supervised Learning

3.1 Regression

Linear Regression
[ = Xw + b]

Loss: Mean Squared Error (MSE)
Solution: Normal equation / Gradient descent



Regularization

Ridge (L2)
Lasso (L1)




3.2 Classification

Logistic Regression
[ P(y=1|x) = (w^Tx)]

Loss: Binary Cross-Entropy



k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN)

Distance-based classifier



Support Vector Machines (SVM)

Maximum margin classifier
Kernel trick

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
4. Unsupervised Learning

4.1 Clustering

k-Means

Objective: Minimize within-cluster variance



Hierarchical Clustering

Agglomerative vs Divisive



DBSCAN

Density-based clustering




4.2 Dimensionality Reduction

Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

Variance maximization
Eigen decomposition of covariance matrix



t-SNE / UMAP

Non-linear visualization methods

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
5. Model Evaluation

Metrics

Accuracy
Precision, Recall, F1-score
ROC–AUC



Validation Techniques

Train/Test split
k-fold Cross-validation



Bias–Variance Tradeoff

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
6. Learning Theory (Brief)

Empirical Risk Minimization (ERM)
Structural Risk Minimization (SRM)
VC Dimension
Generalization bounds

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
7. Neural Networks (Overview)

Artificial Neural Network (ANN)

Perceptron model
Activation functions: ReLU, Sigmoid, Tanh



Training

Backpropagation
Gradient descent



Overfitting Control

Dropout
Early stopping

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
8. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)

Convolution layer
Pooling layer
Fully connected layer

Applications:

Image classification
Change detection

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
9. Practical Considerations

Data Preprocessing

Normalization / Standardization
Handling missing values



Feature Engineering

Domain knowledge
Multiscale features

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
10. Tools & Libraries

Python
NumPy, Pandas
Scikit-learn
TensorFlow / PyTorch

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
11. Summary
Machine Learning combines mathematical foundations, algorithms, and data-driven experimentation to solve real-world problems efficiently.


These notes are designed to be concise and extensible. You can add code blocks, datasets, and experiments directly in Quarto.

title: A sample work
text:
For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see Figure 1.


Code
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()








Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis
